signature.instructions:
Given the fields `question`, produce the fields `answer`.

You will be given `question` and your goal is to finish with `answer`.

To do this, you will interleave Thought, Tool Name, and Tool Args, and receive a resulting Observation.

Thought can reason about the current situation, and Tool Name can be the following types:

(1) AdvancedSearch, whose description is <desc>Searches documents using a search_query.  Arguments:  - "search_query": an optimized search query for dense passage retrieval.  IMPORTANT: YOU MUST always PROVIDE "search_query" in the arguments!</desc>. It takes arguments {'search_query': 'str', 'trajectory_id': 'Union[str, NoneType]'} in JSON format.
(2) finish, whose description is <desc>Signals that the final outputs, i.e. `answer`, are now available and marks the task as complete.</desc>. It takes arguments {} in JSON format.

demos.question: Which lasted longer, the Battle of Belleau Wood or the Battle of Leyte?
demos.trajectory:
[[ ## tool_name_init ## ]]
AdvancedSearch

[[ ## tool_args_init ## ]]
{"search_query": "Which lasted longer, the Battle of Belleau Wood or the Battle of Leyte?"}

[[ ## thought_init ## ]]
I will start by searching for relevant documents with the original question as the search query.

[[ ## observation_init ## ]]
{"search_query": "Which lasted longer, the Battle of Belleau Wood or the Battle of Leyte?", "passages_this_hop": [{"long_text": "Belleau Wood\nBelleau Wood may refer to:\n- The Battle of Belleau Wood, near Château-Thierry, France, the scene of heavy fighting by U.S. Marines in World War I\n- USS Belleau Wood, two United States Navy ships that have been named after the Battle:\n- USS \"Belleau Wood\" (CVL-24), a light aircraft carrier (1942–1953), later in the French Navy as the \"Bois Belleau\" (1953–1960)\n- USS \"Belleau Wood\" (LHA-3), an", "score": 0.82177734375}, {"long_text": "Battle of Leyte\nThe Battle of Leyte (Filipino: \"Labanan sa Leyte\", Waray: \"Gubat ha Leyte\", 17 October – 26 December 1944) in the Pacific campaign of World War II was the amphibious invasion of the island of Leyte in the Philippines by American forces and Filipino guerrillas under the command of General Douglas MacArthur, who fought against the Imperial Japanese Army in the Philippines led by General Tomoyuki Yamashita. The operation, codenamed \"King Two\", launched the Philippines campaign of 1944–45 for", "score": 0.822265625}, {"long_text": "Battle of Leyte Gulf\nThe Battle of Leyte Gulf (Filipino: \"Labanan sa Look ng Leyte\") is considered to have been the largest naval battle of World War II and, by some criteria, possibly the largest naval battle in history, with over 200,000 naval personnel involved. It was fought in waters near the Philippine islands of Leyte, Samar, and Luzon, from 23–26 October 1944, between combined American and Australian forces and the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN), as part of the invasion of Leyte,", "score": 0.822265625}, {"long_text": "Battle of Belleau Wood\nThe Battle of Belleau Wood (1–26 June 1918) occurred during the German Spring Offensive in World War I, near the Marne River in France. The battle was fought between the U.S. 2nd (under the command of Major General Omar Bundy) and 3rd Divisions along with French and British forces against an assortment of German units including elements from the 237th, 10th, 197th, 87th, and 28th Divisions. The battle has become a key component of the lore of the United States Marine Corps.", "score": 0.83056640625}, {"long_text": "USS Belleau Wood (CVL-24)\nUSS \"Belleau Wood was a United States Navy light aircraft carrier active during World War II in the Pacific Theater from 1943 to 1945. The ship also served in the First Indochina War under French Navy temporary service as Bois Belleau\".\nOriginally laid down as the New Haven\" (CL-76), she was finished as an aircraft carrier. Reclassified CV-24 on 16 February 1942 and renamed Belleau Wood\" on 31 March 1942 in honor of the Battle of Belleau Wood in World War I.", "score": 0.83447265625}]}

[[ ## thought_0 ## ]]
Next, I will analyze the passages to determine which battle lasted longer.

[[ ## tool_name_0 ## ]]
AdvancedSearch

[[ ## tool_args_0 ## ]]
{"search_query": "Which battle lasted longer, the Battle of Belleau Wood or the Battle of Leyte?", "trajectory_id": "Leyte"}

[[ ## observation_0 ## ]]
{"search_query": "Which battle lasted longer, the Battle of Belleau Wood or the Battle of Leyte?", "passages_this_hop": [{"long_text": "Leyte\nelectric power plants near Ormoc.\nHowever, Leyte is most famous for its role in the reconquest of the Philippines in World War II. On 20 October 1944, General Douglas MacArthur waded ashore on Leyte, saying, \"I have returned\", but the Japanese did not give up so easily, as the ensuing Battle of Leyte proved. The convergence of naval forces resulted in the four-day Battle of Leyte Gulf, the largest naval battle in history.\nGeography.\nThe island measures about north-south", "score": 0.8017578125}, {"long_text": "Leyte (province)\nSpanish explorer Ruy López de Villalobos in honor of Prince Philip of Spain, used to refer to the islands of Leyte and Samar only, until it was adopted to refer to the entire archipelago.\nLeyte is also known as the site of the largest naval battle in modern history, the Battle of Leyte Gulf, which took place during the Second World War.\nLeyte is especially prone to typhoons because of its geographic facing toward the Pacific Ocean. On 8 November 2013, the province was severely affected by Super Typhoon Yolanda", "score": 0.80224609375}, {"long_text": "USS Belleau Wood (CVL-24)\nOctober), and the Battle of Cape Engaño (24–26 October). On 30 October, while \"Belleau Wood\" was patrolling with her task group east of Leyte, she shot down a Japanese \"kamikaze\" plane which fell on her flight deck aft, causing fires which set off ammunition. Before the fire could be brought under control, 92 men had either died or were missing.\nAfter temporary repairs at Ulithi (2–11 November), \"Belleau Wood\" steamed to Hunters Point, California, for permanent repairs", "score": 0.806640625}, {"long_text": "Battle off Samar\nThe Battle off Samar (Filipino: \"Labanan sa may Samar\") was the centermost action of the Battle of Leyte Gulf, one of the largest naval battles in history, which took place in the Philippine Sea off Samar Island, in the Philippines on October 25, 1944. It was the only major action in the larger battle where the Americans were largely unprepared against the opposing forces. The Battle off Samar has been cited by historians as one of the greatest last stands in naval history.", "score": 0.81689453125}, {"long_text": "USS Belleau Wood (LHA-3)\nthemselves at Belleau Wood. In that tradition, Marines of the Fourth Brigade are permitted to wear the French fourragère to this day.\nTwelve gold battle stars in a field of blue line the top of the coat of arms. They stand for the World War II record of the first . The gap between the sixth and seventh stars represents the ship's only break in her war record. On 30 October 1944, while off Leyte Gulf, \"Belleau Wood\" was struck by a kamikaze. The light aircraft carrier had", "score": 0.81982421875}]}

The passages indicate that the Battle of Leyte lasted longer than the Battle of Belleau Wood.

[[ ## tool_name_1 ## ]]
finish

[[ ## tool_args_1 ## ]]

demos.trajectory:
[[ ## tool_name_init ## ]]

{"search_query": "What precious metal did both McIntyre Mines and the Kemess Mine dig for?", "passages_this_hop": [{"long_text": "McIntyre Mines\nProject is a registry for miners who have health issues and who have been exposed to McIntyre Powder aluminum dust.\nBetween 1912 and 1955 production was valued at $230 million and the company paid $62 million in dividends to shareholders. From 1912 to 1988 there were 37,529,691 tons milled, producing 10,745,361 ounces of gold, an overall grade of 0.29 ounces per ton. In the early 1960s a substantial body of copper ore was noted north west of the old #6 shaft. By 1965 this was put into production and was", "score": 0.80859375}, {"long_text": "Kemess Mine\ncreating a new company called AuRico Metals.\nAuRico Metals was acquired by Centerra Gold in January 2018.\nThe deposit mined was a copper-gold porphyry. Over its life the mine produced approximately 3 million ounces of gold and 800 million pounds of copper.\nThe mine is serviced by Kemess Creek Airport and the Omineca Resource Road from Prince George. Air distance from Smithers is 280 km, approximately due north; road distance from Prince George is approximately 550 km.\nNear the mine is the Kemess Underground Project,", "score": 0.8203125}, {"long_text": "Kemess Creek Airport\nKemess Creek Airport, , is located near Kemess Mine, British Columbia, Canada.", "score": 0.8271484375}, {"long_text": "McIntyre Mines\nThe McIntyre mine is an abandoned underground gold mine in Schumacher, Ontario, Canada, which has earned a place in Canadian mining history as one of the nation's most important mines. Its iconic headframe, located near downtown Timmins, has come to represent the entire Porcupine Gold Rush. The McIntyre also yielded a considerable amount of copper over its life.\nThere has been an extensive degree of rehabilitation and exploration work performed in and around the old McIntyre Mine property in recent years, and the Porcupine Joint Venture", "score": 0.8310546875}, {"long_text": "Kemess Mine\nThe Kemess Mine was an open-pit copper and gold mine, located just northeast of the foot of Thutade Lake, at the head of the Finlay River, in the Omineca Mountains of the Northern Interior of British Columbia, Canada. It was operated by Royal Oak Mines from 1998 to 1999, when it was bought by Northgate Minerals. Northgate operated the mine until its closure in 2011; that year Northgate was taken over by AuRico Gold. In 2014 AuRico Gold partitioned off its portion of Kemess Mine ownership", "score": 0.8427734375}]}

demos.reasoning: The precious metal that both McIntyre Mines and the Kemess Mine dug for was determined through a series of searches and analyses. The original question was searched for relevant documents, which provided information about the mines. The passages from the search results were then analyzed to determine the precious metal that both mines dug for. The analysis revealed that both mines produced a significant amount of gold over their lifetimes. Further searches were conducted to confirm this information and to determine if gold is a precious metal commonly associated with both gold and copper mining. The results of these searches supported the conclusion that gold is the precious metal that both McIntyre Mines and the Kemess Mine dug for.
